segments.text: Why do you feel as if we possibly get better data from our, or as good a data from our vessels as the Soviet Union does with, in terms of funding of expedition, sizes of expedition?
Is there any explanation for that, or have I inferred wrong?
I find it difficult to make this kind of a comparison.
I'm saying that I'm frequently asked to compare

the Russian with the US that seems to be a let's see that's a question which intrigues people much more than say comparing US with England or with France or so on I find that comparison difficult to make that's the point some people find it easier than I do I I
Both in, let's see, people are interested in the level of technology, in the magnitude of the achievement, in the quality of the work, and so on.
And to me, it's not an easy question to answer.
It's not conspicuously one way or the other.
It depends on the individual situation.
OK.
Just eliminate the next three questions I was going to ask you about that.
Do you have any views on the role that sea conferences have played in bringing together international cooperation?
You mean international meetings, scientific meetings?
Scientific meetings are very important, more so in oceanography, I think,
many other fields because of the fact that the oceans, the study of the oceans is very much an international field in which many countries share in exchange of information dealing with the ocean.
Do you see the pushing of nations' boundaries out more deeply or further into the ocean?
as a threat to your particular academic history.
Well, it makes it more difficult.
Yes, the oceanography is getting more involved in problems of the jurisdiction over the sea, yes.
Do you feel as if perhaps that these international conferences will aid in this sort of thing, us being allowed and they being allowed to work closer on the continental shelves?
are closer to boundaries?
Well, in principle, it could.
At the moment, it isn't obvious that it is helpful.
Excuse me.

The next series of questions I should like to ask have to do with your opinions of education in oceanography and possibly the future of oceanography, or oceanography's contribution to the future, if I could.
Do you see any marked change in terms of education of oceanographers that has occurred in the last 15 or 20 years?
Let's see.
There's always a continuing change in education in the sense that there is no dogma, no routine.
The whole oceanography is a developing field.
And the education of oceanographers goes along with the development of knowledge.
So it's continually changing.
And I mean, that's basic.
That's basic.
I'm not sure that answers your question.
Well, do you see the rise of oceanography departments as specific departments in academic institutions as essentially a good thing that's occurred the last several years?
Oh, well, yes, in the sense that it's led to an increased knowledge of the ocean,
I'm not sure what you're getting at.
OK. Well, let me try to explain it more clearly.

I'm struck by the way that the original development of oceanography had to do with people drifting into oceanography, if I may use that metaphor, from other academic disciplines and sort of developing
from geophysics, from work in seismology, like Professor Shore next to you, or what have you, and then moving to a place like Scripps Institution and creating oceanography.
And with the impact of ONR, in particular, and NSL after the war, there have been developed now specialized departments of oceanography.
Yes.
Along with this developed oceanography, there's a continuing
flux of people from other fields, from physics, chemistry, mathematics, whatnot.
There's a continuing flux of people from those fields into the oceanographic field.
That hasn't stopped.
In other words, people that are in oceanography don't come exclusively from these oceanographic departments.

So let's say the existence of departments of oceanography and degrees being given in oceanography, to me, is not a fundamental change in the situation of education in oceanography, in part because the people
Within the Department of Oceanography, the people that work within the Departments of Oceanography themselves are working in disciplines similar to in other non-oceanographic departments.
They tend to be chemists, geologists, geophysicists, physicists working in oceanography.
continue this kind of disciplinary studies right within the department.
So this, to me, existence of departments of oceanography, to me, is not a fundamental departure, not a fundamental change in the science of oceanography.
Is it possible that there are too many departments of oceanography now?
Oh.
I couldn't answer that question.
I don't think so.
It would be, let's see, the growth of any field I think is better in many ways if growth by proliferation of institutions rather than
few of them going to colossal size.
One of the problems, I think, in oceanography is that ships are very expensive.
And small oceanographic institutions would have a greater difficulty in keeping a ship going.
Even a large institution like Scripps Institution, which is one of the largest
possibly the largest, has difficulty maintaining its fleet of ships.
But there are some advantages, don't you see, in small institutions?
Such as?
Well, there's an advantage of more, let's say, simpler relations between the people involved in a more, kind of a more intimate
contact among your people.
When things get large, they get problems just because they are large, and problems of administration, for example.
Was the establishment of the University of California at San Diego beneficial for Scripps?
I think so, yes.
I think, yes, that has the contact with the
An expanded university's been beneficial to Scripps, in my opinion.
Then there seems to be some perfect size you're speaking of.
Is, in your opinion, Scripps Institution now too large?
Oh, I'd hate to make an opinion about that.
Some aspects of it, it's too large.
I look with some nostalgia back in the period when I knew everybody here.
And now I don't.
I go to a gathering of people that they tell me are all from Christian institutions.
I may know about 10% of them.
So I think of the good old days when I knew everybody.
The ocean has been looked upon, fortunately or unfortunately, in the 60s as a possible solution to man's problems in terms of food, mineral resources, and so forth.
Are you optimistic about that sort of approach to the ocean?
Let's say you're getting into a subject that, in my opinion, is really not worth much.
The, yes, I think there have been maybe too much optimism about the, what some people almost think of as the inexhaustible resources of the sea.
Let's see, and
In some of those resources, I think we're already pushing pretty close to the limit.
Some of the fish, fishing in the sea, for example, pretty clearly quails and so on.
Many things that at one time looked like they were inexhaustible in the sea are now quite clearly not inexhaustible.
So no, I don't look for a real tremendous development where the sea can provide almost limitless possibilities.
There's some resources of the sea are not
being utilized yet, for example, on the sea bottom.
And there are projects for mining the deep sea floor, for example.
I think you'd better ask somebody else about that field.
What do you see as, may I call it, the future of oceanography?
That is, what direction do you see your particular discipline taking?
in the immediate future?
Oh, I don't see it.
It bothers me a little bit.
The future seemed very clear to me at the end of the wars in 1946.
The immediate future seemed very clear to me at that time.
It doesn't seem so to me right now.
Maybe that's because I'm old.
don't really see it very clearly.
There's always a hope, I think, that there'll be a breakthrough or some unforeseen development.
All of the exciting things that have happened to me in my oceanographic life couldn't have been foreseen, couldn't have been thought of because they were discovered in the process.
So when I say the thing seemed clear to me, it wasn't that I
I predicted or imagined everything that was going to be discovered.
But what I meant was what seemed clear was the way to go.
And now it seems to you as if oceanography is spreading in many particular directions.
I think the reason it isn't clear is it's much more complex now.
And we're utilizing facilities and ideas that are much more complex than ones we've worked on
30 years ago, or 25 or whatever it was when I started.
Okay.
Now, what are your intentions in future research?
Well, I'm sort of, it's hard for me to know how to go.
I'm retired, you know.
I retired a year ago.
So I'm sort of...

In a way, I have two, I think maybe one of my major responsibilities right now is just sort of cleaning house in a way, sort of winding up some of the things that I've been doing and trying to throw away a lot of the things that aren't
aren't needed to hang on to.
Some of the things that we've acquired in the process, and I think this is true of many fields of oceanography, you acquire, in a sense, archives.
The biologists may have acquired a whole lot of specimens of things that they put in bottles of formaldehyde one time.
And geologists collect rocks off the seafloor, and also cores of sediment.
These are archives which are useful for people later on.
Questions come up that can be solved by reference to these archives of material, the cores that
that have been studied in a preliminary way that contain information that no one dreamed maybe was important at all at the time they did it.
And our work here has similar archives.
We have seismic records that are continuing to be useful to people.
Many people come to examine details that, when we first look at them,
We didn't have time or weren't even aware that they might be important.

So I have some interest in cleaning up the archive so that the material that's useful will be retained and the stuff that isn't just in the way will be thrown away or put off to one side or just stacked up.
There's a lot else to use.
In addition to that, I'm still somewhat in demand to go to sea to participate in continuing work to be on contract proposals as an investigator and so on.
So I'm continuing to do that.
In fact, I'm on two coming expeditions, one going out in September, and I'm also going out in January.
I hope the one in Journeyware is to the south.
Well, it's almost the same place.
The ship will still be there, you see.
One of the things is it costs a good deal of money to get a ship out into that area.
And the most interesting parts of the world to study are far from Scripps.
And that isn't entirely because we've studied everything close by and we have to go further away.
There are just a whole lot of
more interesting geology and geophysics in areas like the Southeast Asia, which is a fascinating, very complex region.
So complicated that it's only recently that people are getting into it, because it's very hard to understand.
And the region that we're immediately adjacent to California, the region of the ocean right off here, is a simple, comparatively simple area.
In terms of the field that we're doing, the geophysics of the ocean bottom.
So we have our ship out there now.
It's in Guam.
It's coming into Guam very soon.
It's the fifth.
Monday it's coming into Guam.
And then it's going to be out there for another six months on various
before he comes back to San Diego.
